awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Integration and Culture Change
awd_abstract_narration:
The current climate crisis is a stark reminder of humanity’s shared history of dealing with climatic extremes. In archeological theory, climate change or natural disasters have been blamed for the collapse of civilizations. Equally common, however, are instances in which polities in the ancient world adapted to or circumvented climatic extremes. Learning how ancient people dealt with severe climate phenomena can inform current and future responses to such crises. Archaeology is exceptionally positioned to unearth the long record of mutual interactions between human cultural practices and their environments. This project will examine ancient human resilience to climatic extremes at the archaeological site directly affected by El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events. Since the mid-Holocene societies have experienced ENSO events that, when most powerful, transform ecological conditions, prompting heavy rainfall and flooding in some locations and severe drought in others. This project takes a community-engaged approach to excavation and analysis. Through hiring and training residents, distributing educational resources, offering recurring presentations at schools, and preparing cultural heritage exhibitions this project will provide long-term community benefits. In this way, archeological work will be made relevant to local people. This project aims to respect, record, and integrate Indigenous knowledge systems, broadening the vision of climate science to incorporate traditional and local knowledge. 

Focusing on an area directly affected by ENSO events, this research investigates three resilient ways in which people integrated ENSO-related changes into their social and ecological systems. First, in the local dimension residents had access to various ecological niches, including floodplain, ocean and desert environments.. Thus, ENSO events that disrupt traditional irrigation canals and maritime resources also offer opportunities in desert landscapes, prompting extensive biota growth. This raises the question of how people in the area took advantage of such fluctuations. In addition to differentially affecting ecological niches, ENSOs have varying impacts on neighboring coastal valleys. As a second adaptation to these events, this project tests for trade between groups of people inhabiting the coastal zone.Finally the region was a strategic forefront of maritime resources and likely participated in subsistence exchanges with people inhabiting higher, agriculturally-focused sites of the valley. ENSOs affect resource availability across the various altitudinally-determined ecological zones, so this project will also investigate coastal-highland resource exchanges as an  ENSO-resilience strategy. In conclusion, this project will combine climate modeling and archaeological data from site levels before, during, and after significant ENSO events to explore local resilience and determine how patterns of exchange fluctuated as fundamental human adaptations to ENSO events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explores Viru (c.a. 200 B.C. to A.D. 600) subsistence strategies at the site of Puerto Malabrigo in the Chicama Valley on the north coast of Peru, an area directly affected by Eastern Pacific El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events. The Viru people originated in the Viru Valley, south of the Moche and Chicama valleys. According to Millaire and colleagues 2016, the presence of Viru-negative ceramics at sites outside the Viru Valley, specifically at Cerro Oreja, Pampa La Cruz, and Huaca Las Estrellas in the Moche Valley and Huaca Prieta in the Chicama Valley, indicate Viru settlements that were politically and economically linked to the Viru state. At the site of Puerto Malabrigo, we are quite certain we are dealing with a Viru occupation. For the Viru people, Malabrigo would have been a strategic position, one that was located at the northernmost point of the Chicama floodplain within the coastal zone and with access to varied resources, including agricultural foods, marine species, guano, salt, resilient desert-dune plants, and wetland resources.

This project, which involved a team of Puerto Malabrigo residents and students from a neighboring university, excavated two trenches within the sunken fields of Malabrigo's wetlands and three household structures in Malabrigo's pampas, the desert dunes that bloom during ENSOs. Excavation findings suggest a Viru occupation, including diagnostic Viru-negative sherds and blue-cream textiles showing exciting connections to other Viru sites and the Viru capital. With our focus on food strategies in a changing environment, we are thrilled to report that excavations revealed a cooking space marked by burnt adobes, a storage space with six vessels, and trash deposits in all units. Field screening recovered various resources, including mollusks Stromonita chocolata, Polinices uber, Donax sp., Mesodesma donacium, Choromytilus chorus, Perumytilus purpuratus, crustacean Playxanthus orbignyi, algae Chondracanthus chamissoi, fish Paralanchurus peruanus, Sciaena deliciosa, Engraulis ringens, wetland-resource Schoenoplectus californicus, and crops Arachis hypogaea, Capsicum spp., Cucurbitaceae, Phaseolus sp., Prosopis spp., Zea mays, and, finally, camelids. During excavations, we collected 441 sedimental samples to recover organic materials through 4.0, 2.0, 1.0, and 0.5-mm screens, using a stereo microscope for the lower fractions. The smaller-sized specimens found in the samples, in combination with foods recovered during excavation course screening, offer a comprehensive understanding of Viru subsistence strategies in the context of a dynamic environment at a site that possibly had intra- and inter-valley connections with other Viru sites.

A better understanding of past food practices and interactions with ENSOs might elucidate techniques to increase resilience in the face of exacerbated climatic circumstances in the present era. The archaeobotanical methods used in this study may also provide valuable archival data surrounding the documentation of ancestral seeds that often contain important genetic information, like adaptations for heat or drought. Archaeological research in Latin America works best when national and international specialists work closely with the local public and descendent communities. In awareness, this project takes a collaborative approach to excavation and analysis by respecting and recording Indigenous knowledge, while also training and hiring residents. Our long-term efforts include distributing educational resources within the local community, offering reoccurring presentations and workshops to local students and people, and helping prepare educational and cultural heritage exhibitions. We believe it is critical not to miss opportunities to overcome the divide between academic knowledge production and the input of members of the communities on whose land we work.
